caption_text: To take the maximum controllable step, a raster is constructed in the furnace (Fig. 1). First, Type-A regions are defined. Each of them contains an entire row of tubes.

caption_text: To reduce the required computer storage capacity, the contributions of the different bands to the radiative heat exchange are added up according to their weight in the Planck distribution (Fig. 2). Direct-exchange areas among surface zones are then obtained by multiplying F~ by the emitter area. To calculate the direct-exchange area from a surface to a volume zone, fictitious surface zones delimiting the gas zones were introduced in the previous work.
raw_window: To reduce the required computer storage capacity, the contributions of the different bands to the radiative heat exchange are added up according to their weight in the Planck distribution (Fig. 2).
Direct-exchange areas among surface zones are then obtained by multiplying F~ by the emitter area.
To calculate the direct-exchange area from a surface to a volume zone, fictitious surface zones delimiting the gas zones were introduced in the previous work.

caption_text: The flue gas velocity induced by one burner at a particular point in the furnace is calculated as shown in Fig. 3. For a point located inside the cone (zone I in Fig. 3), the flue gas velocity is a vector that is directed away from the cone top T and that has a magnitude inversely proportional to the square of the distance between P1 and T. In zone II, above the cone, the flue gas flow is supposed to be homogeneously distributed.
raw_window: The flue gas velocity induced by one burner at a particular point in the furnace is calculated as shown in Fig. 3.

For a point located inside the cone (zone I in Fig. 3), the flue gas velocity is a vector that is directed away from the cone top T and that has a magnitude inversely proportional to the square of the distance between P1 and T.
In zone II, above the cone, the flue gas flow is supposed to be homogeneously distributed.

caption_text: In Fig. 4, the final flue gas velocities in a section of the furnace are shown. The cone top angle in this par- ticular case was 60 . The flue gas flow in the vicinity of the oven walls and of the reactor tubes is almost 2 P2 ZonelI Zone I VI v3~O P3 Zone m Fig. 3.

caption_text: A schematical represen- tation of the coil configuration and the subdivision into zones is given in Fig. 6. For the simulation of the cracking process, an extended version of the detailed radical reaction scheme proposed by Sundaram and Froment (1981) is used in combination with a one- dimensional plug flow model for the reactor (Froment, 1981). The kinetic scheme contains about 150 reactions between 14 molecular species and 12 radicals.
raw_window: A schematical represen- tation of the coil configuration and the subdivision into zones is given in Fig. 6.

For the simulation of the cracking process, an extended version of the detailed radical reaction scheme proposed by Sundaram and Froment (1981) is used in combination with a one- dimensional plug flow model for the reactor (Froment, 1981).
The kinetic scheme contains about 150 reactions between 14 molecular species and 12 radicals.

caption_text: In Fig. 7, the temperatures of the furnace walls and the flue gas are given as a function of the height in the furnace. Because of the combined side wall and bottom firing, the flue gas temperature gradient is quite steep. Consequently, the heat flux along the cracking coil varies considerably with the axial coordinate (Fig. 8).
raw_window: In Fig. 7, the temperatures of the furnace walls and the flue gas are given as a function of the height in the furnace.
Because of the combined side wall and bottom firing, the flue gas temperature gradient is quite steep.
Consequently, the heat flux along the cracking coil varies considerably with the axial coordinate (Fig. 8).

caption_text: The axial tube metal temperature profile, which is shown in Fig. 9, follows the shape of the heat flux profile. The temperature peaks are important for the choice of the tube material. They also lead to severe and localized coke formation in the lower U-bends, causing a high pressure drop and therefore a loss in the selectivity for the main cracking product, ethylene, and reducing the run length of the furnace between decok- ing periods.
raw_window: The axial tube metal temperature profile, which is shown in Fig. 9, follows the shape of the heat flux profile.
The temperature peaks are important for the choice of the tube material.

They also lead to severe and localized coke formation in the lower U-bends, causing a high pressure drop and therefore a loss in the selectivity for the main cracking product, ethylene, and reducing the run length of the furnace between decok- ing periods.

caption_text: The process gas temperature (Fig. 10) is relatively insensitive to the flux variations. This is due to the high mass flow rate in the reactor, which dampens changes in heat input, and to the endothermic nature of the pyrolysis process, that has a self- stabilizing effect on the process gas temperature. Table 2 compares the simulated results with the industrial measurements.

Table 2 compares the simulated results with the industrial measurements.
